awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will increase the body of knowledge on the genomics of bacteriophages. 

The goals of Salish Kootenai College's Science Education Alliance-Phage Hunters Advancing Genomics and Evolutionary Science in Tribal Colleges and Universities (SEA-PHAGES in TCUs) Project are to provide exciting professional development opportunities for STEM faculty, expand research-based learning opportunities for STEM students, and build institutional research capacity through participation in the SEA-PHAGES curriculum offered in partnership with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI). Faculty and students will isolate, identify, sequence and analyze newly discovered mycobacteriophages gathered from the local environment as part of a long-term, nationwide study. Faculty at SKC will learn novel laboratory procedures, participate in national training workshops, and enhance their research skills and knowledge. Students enrolled in the dual-credit STEM Academy will study genomics and bioinformatics, gain valuable hands-on laboratory experience, and participate in cutting edge research. Knowledge and skills gathered through this project will provide a strong foundation for future teaching and research in genomics, biotechnology and bioinformatics at Salish Kootenai College.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF-TCUP Salish Kootenai College SEA-PHAGES?

Project Outcomes

Award Number:  1800347

 

NSF-TCUP SKC SEA-PHAGES objectives were in conjunction with a NIH-SEPA grant.  Both grant objectives are also listed below, followed by the merits and broader impacts of these projects.

 SKC STEM Academy TCUP SEA-PHAGES Objectives:

 a) Provide students with an authentic experience conducting original scientific research.

 b) Infuse students with excitement about the process of scientific discovery and research.

 c) Build confidence in each student?s ability to operate in a laboratory and to carry out research through the acquisition of foundational laboratory techniques and skills.

 d) Teach students communication and education skills through presentation of their research.

 e) Reach elementary, middle, and high school students to engage them in STEM-related fields.

 f) Provide opportunities for Native Americans to explore coursework and research in the STEM fields, especially biomedical and biobehavioral, to increase the number of Native Americans with college degrees and careers in these underrepresented areas.

 

A Change in Objective or Scope requested June 15, 2022

Approved: June 27, 2022 - Amendment Number 002

 a) Provide middle and high school teachers with authentic science research experiences that will be enacted in the classroom to facilitate STEM pathways for their students, preparing them to enter into dual enrollment and degree-bearing programs at SKC.

 b) Integrate place-based, culturally-congruent curriculum to engage teachers and students on and around the reservation, thereby supporting academic pathways to SKC.

 c) Familiarize science teachers on the Flathead Indian Reservation with SKC and its programs to support the recruitment of students, as SKC is a rich, underserved community resource that serves the greater reservation community.

 

SKC STEM Academy NIH-SEPA Grant Objectives: 

 a) Earn both high school and college credits while completing foundational, culturally-congruent coursework in STEM. (Dual Enrollment)

 b)  Engage in authentic scientific research working collaboratively with STEM professionals and SKC faculty.

 c)  Deliver outreach to area elementary, middle, and high school students, in addition to the greater community to improve their own communication of basic science, generate enthusiasm for STEM-based research in a younger audience, and provide near-peer mentoring.

 

 

Project Outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merits and broader impacts of our NSF-TCUP work:

  • 5 STEM Academy cohorts successfully completed the Howard Hughes Medical Institute?s authentic scientific research SEA-PHAGES Program, which is a larger national/international program who have manage large research projects for over 15 years.
  • 4 cohorts successfully completed the University of Montana Research Education on Air and Cardiovascular Health (REACH) program.
  • Surveys indicated student?s abilities to operate in a lab and carry out research techniques increased 100 fold as this type of course is not offered in the local high schools.
  • The participating students gained experience by presenting their research in poster and oral formats at scientific conferences:  HHMI SEA-PHAGES; REACH; and T-CUP Symposiums. 
  • Student communication skills were gained in reading, analyzing and presenting of scientific articles to their peers during their research courses. 
  • Survey results indicate that participating STEM Academy students gained, strong non-cognitive skills related to attitudes toward research and their own career goals as well as gains in growth mindset and self-efficacy.
  • Evaluation results suggest the STEM Academy curriculum and experiences increase students? level of scientific reasoning.
  • Local participating high school students in STEM Academy were given the rare opportunity to analyze and annotate the DNA sequences using bioinformatics.
  • SKC STEM Academy students successfully isolated 17 novel phages and 5 genome annotations to date.
  • 43 students in five cohorts participated in the STEM Academy; 86% were American Indian, 100% were rural.
  • 83% of STEM Academy students who enrolled/will be enrolled in college.
  • High school students who enrolled in STEM Academy as juniors, and fully participated for two years could receive approximately half or more credits necessary to earn a General Science Associate degree at SKC.
  • Approximately 3,250 K-12 students and community members have participated in STEM Academy outreach efforts (COVID-19 prevented in-person outreach in the 2019-2021).
  • The recent Change in Scope last June allowed teachers in the local area to gain professional development in the SEA-PHAGES protocols. 
  • The SEA-PHAGES are now being integrated into local high school and middle school courses. Over 800 hundred participating students per/year receive instruction in biomedical protocols.
  • Native Americans are severely underrepresented in science as well as the STEM workforce and the project addressed this disparity, thus benefitting many students on the Flathead Reservation.
  • The collaboration of these grants, NSF-TCUP and NIH-SEPA ultimately increased the number of Native Americans in STEM fields, particularly in the biomedical sciences.   
  • The students enrolled in these projects are better prepared to enter college and successfully graduate, thus leading to significant broader impacts for them in the future. 

 We feel this research project was well-designed and focused on Native American high school students with many objectives gained in the four years of the NSF-TCUP grant.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Mary Larson

por.por_txt_cntn:
NSF-TCUP Salish Kootenai College SEA-PHAGES? 
Project Outcomes
Award Number:  1800347

 

NSF-TCUP SKC SEA-PHAGES objectives were in conjunction with a NIH-SEPA grant.  Both grant objectives are also listed below, followed by the merits and broader impacts of these projects.

 SKC STEM Academy TCUP SEA-PHAGES Objectives:

 a) Provide students with an authentic experience conducting original scientific research.

 b) Infuse students with excitement about the process of scientific discovery and research.

 c) Build confidence in each student?s ability to operate in a laboratory and to carry out research through the acquisition of foundational laboratory techniques and skills.

 d) Teach students communication and education skills through presentation of their research.

 e) Reach elementary, middle, and high school students to engage them in STEM-related fields.

 f) Provide opportunities for Native Americans to explore coursework and research in the STEM fields, especially biomedical and biobehavioral, to increase the number of Native Americans with college degrees and careers in these underrepresented areas.

 

A Change in Objective or Scope requested June 15, 2022

Approved: June 27, 2022 - Amendment Number 002

 a) Provide middle and high school teachers with authentic science research experiences that will be enacted in the classroom to facilitate STEM pathways for their students, preparing them to enter into dual enrollment and degree-bearing programs at SKC.

 b) Integrate place-based, culturally-congruent curriculum to engage teachers and students on and around the reservation, thereby supporting academic pathways to SKC.

 c) Familiarize science teachers on the Flathead Indian Reservation with SKC and its programs to support the recruitment of students, as SKC is a rich, underserved community resource that serves the greater reservation community.

 

SKC STEM Academy NIH-SEPA Grant Objectives: 

 a) Earn both high school and college credits while completing foundational, culturally-congruent coursework in STEM. (Dual Enrollment)

 b)  Engage in authentic scientific research working collaboratively with STEM professionals and SKC faculty.

 c)  Deliver outreach to area elementary, middle, and high school students, in addition to the greater community to improve their own communication of basic science, generate enthusiasm for STEM-based research in a younger audience, and provide near-peer mentoring.

 

 

Project Outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merits and broader impacts of our NSF-TCUP work:

5 STEM Academy cohorts successfully completed the Howard Hughes Medical Institute?s authentic scientific research SEA-PHAGES Program, which is a larger national/international program who have manage large research projects for over 15 years.


4 cohorts successfully completed the University of Montana Research Education on Air and Cardiovascular Health (REACH) program.


Surveys indicated student?s abilities to operate in a lab and carry out research techniques increased 100 fold as this type of course is not offered in the local high schools.


The participating students gained experience by presenting their research in poster and oral formats at scientific conferences:  HHMI SEA-PHAGES; REACH; and T-CUP Symposiums. 


Student communication skills were gained in reading, analyzing and presenting of scientific articles to their peers during their research courses. 


Survey results indicate that participating STEM Academy students gained, strong non-cognitive skills related to attitudes toward research and their own career goals as well as gains in growth mindset and self-efficacy.


Evaluation results suggest the STEM Academy curriculum and experiences increase students? level of scientific reasoning.


Local participating high school students in STEM Academy were given the rare opportunity to analyze and annotate the DNA sequences using bioinformatics.


SKC STEM Academy students successfully isolated 17 novel phages and 5 genome annotations to date.


43 students in five cohorts participated in the STEM Academy; 86% were American Indian, 100% were rural.


83% of STEM Academy students who enrolled/will be enrolled in college.


High school students who enrolled in STEM Academy as juniors, and fully participated for two years could receive approximately half or more credits necessary to earn a General Science Associate degree at SKC.


Approximately 3,250 K-12 students and community members have participated in STEM Academy outreach efforts (COVID-19 prevented in-person outreach in the 2019-2021).
The recent Change in Scope last June allowed teachers in the local area to gain professional development in the SEA-PHAGES protocols. 


The SEA-PHAGES are now being integrated into local high school and middle school courses. Over 800 hundred participating students per/year receive instruction in biomedical protocols.


Native Americans are severely underrepresented in science as well as the STEM workforce and the project addressed this disparity, thus benefitting many students on the Flathead Reservation.


The collaboration of these grants, NSF-TCUP and NIH-SEPA ultimately increased the number of Native Americans in STEM fields, particularly in the biomedical sciences.   


The students enrolled in these projects are better prepared to enter college and successfully graduate, thus leading to significant broader impacts for them in the future.  


 We feel this research project was well-designed and focused on Native American high school students with many objectives gained in the four years of the NSF-TCUP grant.

 

					Last Modified: 01/28/2023

					Submitted by: Mary Larson
